{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3504372,"name":"Eric Lehman","username":"elehman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elehman/{size}/223914_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T21:32:31.308Z","cooked":"

Past CD threads reveal surprising and even bewildering complexity around the humble topic of‚Ä¶ holes. A typical FRC robot has hundreds of holes for fasteners, which hold everything together.

To make sense of this, we made a reference guide that discusses hole sizes, fastener compatibility, drill bits, holding forces, trade-offs, etc. This guide focuses on holes suitable for #10-32 bolts or 3/16" rivets, which many teams use for structural connections. We‚Äôre sharing in the hope that other teams find this helpful. Some material is targeted to our team, but most (such as the summary chart on slide 18) may be of more general interest. At least to the extent that holes are ever of general interest‚Ä¶

Hole Sizes

Some people here know much more about this than we do, so we‚Äôd appreciated comments or corrections. We‚Äôll try to incorporate feedback so the guide doesn‚Äôt mislead people in the future!

elehman:

Past CD threads reveal surprising and even bewildering complexity around the humble topic of‚Ä¶ holes.

Wait till you look into the last 150 years of technical dialogue on holemaking between industry, governments, experts, and the standards organizations

From slide 16

Drill bits are sized with two separate schemes

You‚Äôre forgetting about Letter sizes, which should be common in FRC since a 1/4-20 close fit is a Size F

Letter sizes and number sizes are two halves of the same gauge size system.

This is a great presentation that really clearly lays out how fasteners work and the differences between them, nice work! I did want to comment on this slide:

image877√ó152 10.6 KB

The issue shown here is specific to the scribed tubes, not all versions of it have those scribe lines.
image1729√ó324 40.2 KB

yep, the 3 most used drill bits in our shop are:

  1. #11 drill (for rivets)
  2. F drill (for 1/4-20 bolts) - we only switched from 1/4in drills recently after we realized the fit wasn‚Äôt great
  3. #9 drill (for 10-32 bolts)

After those the most used are probably our step-up larger sizes (and 1.125" reamer) for bearing holes, although they see significantly less use since we‚Äôre no longer making WCD rails

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-02-08T00:52:17.878Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":221,"readers_count":220,"score":49.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485464,"topic_slug":"hole-size-guide","display_username":"Matthew K","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19820,"username":"ArchdukeTim","name":"Tim Winters","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/archduketim/{size}/256125_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55172,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"barn2robotics alumni"},"post_url":"/t/hole-size-guide/485464/7","custom_user_title":"barn2robotics alumni","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3505635,"name":"Aiden S","username":"SonofBeans","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sonofbeans/{size}/128230_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-08T01:13:00.685Z","cooked":"
superdude311:

#11 drill (for rivets)

superdude311:

#9 drill (for 10-32 bolts)

You‚Äôre telling me you‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt just use a 3/16" bit for both of these?

/À¢

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-02-08T01:13:00.685Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":200,"readers_count":199,"score":65.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":485464,"topic_slug":"hole-size-guide","display_username":"Aiden S","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33885,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1684 CAD Mentor, Alum"},"post_url":"/t/hole-size-guide/485464/8","custom_user_title":"1684 CAD Mentor, Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3505715,"name":"NathanNFM","username":"NathanNFM","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathannfm/{size}/181060_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-08T03:06:34.802Z","cooked":"

I just want to start off by saying this is an extremely valuable presentation and does a great job of giving an introduction to this topic.
Since this presentation dances around talking about tolerances, I feel that I should point out that slides 10 to 18 imply that when created (drilled, punched, cut) a hole will be +/- 0.001 from the stated number. This is far from reality. I can‚Äôt speak for the other FRC suppliers directly, but a practice that is very common in industry, and at AndyMark, is to tolerance holes such as these to +/- 0.005. Their location also usually has a +/- 0.005 tolerance. Typically you will find that parts are much more accurate than this, but it‚Äôs not a guarantee. For example, if our sheetmetal vendor already has a punch that will make a 0.194" hole they don‚Äôt have to ask us (sometimes they do anyway) if it‚Äôs okay to use on a part that calls for 0.196. This is true of basically all manufacturing. Since punching holes in aluminium is an extremely repeatable process, all the holes are likely to be +/- 0.001 or better to each other, but they may be up to +/-0.005 away from the number on the print.

If the holes are drilled, and the part is designed well, the designer will usually call out a size that equals a common drill bit size, but the tolerance on a drilled hole is usually always going to be a + tolerance since the drill bit (that is made much more accurate than the part) has to be able to fit in and back out of the hole. Unless you are drilling in a soft material, you can‚Äôt DRILL a hole and get a hole smaller than the drill bit. You should be able to maintain under a +0.005 in diameter with a fully rigid setup, but good luck with a cordless drill‚Ä¶

One more note, You may also see #10 holes sized larger than this if there is a known tolerance stackup that has the potential to cause an issue if all the parts in question are made to the ‚Äúworst case‚Äù of the tolerance. A good example of this is the holes on the flanges of the AM14U6 are called out as 0.210" This isn‚Äôt a transposition error, it‚Äôs because there is enough potential for error introduced at multiple steps in their creation and use* that we felt for a more frustration free assembly process it would be better to make these holes slightly bigger to account for this potential error.

*error includes but is not limited to:

  • The edge of the inside plate relative to the hole
  • This edge being used to locate the bend line
  • The bend line itself relative to its ideal location
  • The deviation of the exact angle of the bend from 90¬∞
  • The above points all again for the outside plate
  • The above points all again for the end sheet
  • The tolerance in the cut length of the churro setting the spacing of the inside and outside plates
  • Any warp along the length of the sheet metal parts.

All 4 of the above mentioned parts in that assembly need to be assembled in 3D space by high school students. The manufacturing tolerances here have the possibility of adding up in such a way that it creates a frustrating assembly experience if every hole is 0.201, especially if every hole is 0.196. This is something we try to avoid on a product that may be a student‚Äôs first time using the assembly tools involved.

I could probably go on here for a while, but TLDR, if you make the boxes shown around the hole size values in the slides 11-18 an accurate height (+5 units and -5 units from ideal) to account for manufacturing tolerances, it gives a more accurate picture of the situation.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-02-08T03:12:09.900Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":175,"readers_count":174,"score":245.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":485464,"topic_slug":"hole-size-guide","display_username":"NathanNFM","primary_group_name":"AndyMark","flair_name":"AndyMark","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/7/2/72db24f824a25ae17c6413b3d02a345e47f060a9.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":59,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":11}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14566,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"AndyMark Senior Mechanical Engineer"},"post_url":"/t/hole-size-guide/485464/9","custom_user_title":"AndyMark Senior Mechanical Engineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":11}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":11,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3505846,"name":"Skuke (aka: Payton)","username":"Skuke","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skuke/{size}/10109_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-08T08:23:42.472Z","cooked":"
NathanNFM:

Unless you are drilling in a soft material, you can‚Äôt DRILL a hole and get a hole smaller than the drill bit.

Agreed. This is an important concept when drilling tight tolerances in common plastics, most notably nylon, teflon, and delrin. I don‚Äôt notice it as much in PC or acrylics.
In the above materials (and others), your hole will likely be SMALLER than the drill bit size.

The heat generated from a fast spinning bit will cause the material to expand. When it returns to ambient, the hole gets smaller. Voila!

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2025-02-08T08:23:42.472Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":127,"readers_count":126,"score":55.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":485464,"topic_slug":"hole-size-guide","display_username":"Skuke (aka: Payton)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32540,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/hole-size-guide/485464/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3505974,"name":"Eric Lehman","username":"elehman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/elehman/{size}/223914_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-08T16:39:17.156Z","cooked":"

Thank you for this fantastic response! There‚Äôs a lot here and going through it all will take me a while, but this is the kind of expert feedback I could only hope for!

Also worth mentioning is bolts under tension, which actually can take much more load than the bolt‚Äôs failure strength. When you tighten a bolt, you squish the nearby material, and because there‚Äôs much more material than bolt, the nearby material is stiffer than the bolt and will take a vast majority of the forces. For this joint to fail in tension, the tensile load has to completely unsqiush the material (equal to the preload of the bolt) and apply some more of the force to the bolt for the joint to separate, which is why bolts in tension can take more force than their preload.

When it comes to boxtube, another high strength mounting method is to drill through one side of the boxtube and only screw into one face of it. This allows lots of pre-load to be applied without a possibility of bending the face of the tube, which generally is strong as long as the face you drilled through isn‚Äôt experiencing high load.

Sometimes it helps to not rely on the bolts/screws alone. Having alignment pins on critical mating parts as structural and locating means can produce quicker and more reliable joints. With this method, you can relax your hole tolerance, which makes it quicker to manufacture. Also, having the right torque requirement and Loctite on structural joint, especially when exposed to vibration are important.
